Honor System Is
Discussed By S. C.
Woolen Will Address
Engineers Thursday
"High Pressure Gas Distribution" Will
Be Subtest Of Illustrated Lecture

Charles E. Woolen will give an
illustrated lecture at a public meeting of Gas Engineers' Association,
to be held Thursday, March 12, in
Room 110 M. E. The talk is scheduled to start at 4.15 P. M. His
subject is to be "High Pressure
Gas Distribution."
This is an entirely new idea in
the utility industry, according to
members of the Association.
Mr. Woolen is assistant superintendent of distribution at the local
Consolidated Gas & Electric Co. It
is expected that there will be a
large attendance present. from both
Hopkins and the gas company.

Enforcement Of Attendance At Asembly By Frosh And Sophs
Brought Up

The Student Council at its meeting last Friday, discussed the adoption of a new system of introducing
incoming classes to the honor system, according to Frank Cone, secretary-treasurer of the organization. Signing of the honor pledge
when the new entrant registers, will
probably be the method used, although details were not disclosed,
as they are not all settled.
Enforcement of assembly attendance by freshmen and sophomores
was the topic under discussion yesterday. This question, too, was also
left unsettled. However, 'members
are certain that a new method will
be inaugurated to cut down on the
large number of absentees.

GREENFIELD ADDRESSES
HOPKINS ALUMNI OF GA.
University History Professor
Talks At Banquet In
Atlanta
FORTY ATTEND BANQUET
•-1

Stresses Fact Hopkins Future
Is 'Not In Past'
Dr. Kent R. Greenfield, Professor of European History, addressed
the Atlanta, Georgia, alumni of the
Johns Hopkins University, at the
annual banquet, held recently at the
Georgian Terrace Hotel. The history professor represented the University at this event.
Alumni from all parts of the
State of Georgia attended the banquet, it was learned. Among the
40 who were present .were physicians and college and university
professors.
Greenfield Addresses Alumni

Dr. Greenfield stressed the fact,
in his address, that "the future of
the Johns Hopkins University is
not in the past, as so many believe."
In speaking of his visit to Atlanta, the Hopkins professor declared that he was greatly impressed
by Emory University, on whose
faculty are several Hopkins graduates.
No Intercollegiate Sports at Emory

It was said that the Hopkins
alumni who are inkructing at
Emory are at present working on
a reorganization of the undergraduate schools similar to that being
attempted here. At the Georgian
institution, said Dr. Greenfield, the
students are apparently uninterested
in intercollegiate sports. "And they
are thoroughly happy about it," he
remarked.

HOLD ANNUAL BALI,
Cosmopolitan Club Entertained At
Affair Saturday Night At Levering

Last Saturday night in the main
ballroom of Levering Hall the Cosnopolitan Club held its annual
dance. A number of non-members
attended the dance. The music
was furnished by a six-piece colored orchestra.

Class Distinctions
To Be Eliminated

9ffice Manager

Chicago, Ill.—An impending revolution in undergraduate life stirs
the campus of the University of
Chicago, according to an Associated
Press release. In the fraternity
houses and commons, in the editorial columns of the Daily Maroon,
wherever students and coeds gather
to chat, talk centers on the metamorphosis of the coming year that
will sweep freshman, sophomore,
junior and senior from the college
vocabulary.
The traditional class system of
the American college is to be submerged, fraternity life overshadowed as students and faculty merge
in a new communal life. The
change is an incident of the Midway Institution's departure—after
only forty years of existence—from
the beaten path of higher education
to experiment with a flexible curriculum that imposes no restriction
on the student's swift path to
learning.

EDITORIALS
TOO MUCH FREEDOM
regulations and as many systems of

types of freshman
MANY
enforcement have been discussed since regulations were abolished

at Hopkins two years agp. There seems to be a manifest need for
some kind of regulation, but the idea of complete freedom has so
permeated Hopkins that undue opposition is always brought to bear
against anyone who is so bold as to suggest that regulations be resumed.
Last year we suggested a plan for enforcing a certain minimum number of regulations of which we approved. The suggestions, however,
seemed to meet with little favor. Since that time several new aspects
to the question have arisen and are well worth bearing in mind.
The construction of some definite program of intramural athletics has been a problem of considerable note at Hopkins during the
past several months. Any program adopted would be aided by some
type of freshman regulation. Since the abolishment of these rules, no
sort of athletic competition between classes has been held. Formerly
football and lacrosse and a track meet were held between the freshman and sophomore classes. Men who otherwise would participate
in no athletics whatsoever were given the opportunities which those
who strongly favor intramural athletics bemoan the lack of at present.
In spite of what may be said to the contrary, the average American
college student likes to feel that he is representing some organization
in any sort of athletic competition. Whether or not this body is a
college, class, or fraternity makes little difference. Freshman regulations are responsible for any organization in the present junior and
senior classes that exists at Hopkins. Few of the freshmen or sophomores know the majority of their classmates either by name or sight.
The requirement that freshmen and sophomores attend assemblies
has not been enforced until recently and hence, the attendance has been
very poor. The two lower classes have little respect for authority. Had
they been accustomed to regulations in their first year of residence, it
is doubtful whether the student could have been compelled to discipline
one-half of the members of the freshman and sophomore classes.
Freedom of action is a fine ideal, but some sort of regulation is certainly
necessary at times.
G. D.

INDIVIDUALS GET COURSE

Annual Conference To Decide

New York.—After a search of
several years for the "ideal college
curriculum," to be used at St.
Stephen's College, the country undergraduate College of Arts and
Letters in Columbia University, located at Annandale-on-Hudson, the
faculty there declared in a New
York Tines article that there is no
such thing and never can be. This
statement was coupled with the announcement that hereafter the college would make an individual curriculum for and with each student.

The Civil En-

persist in referring to them by their previous names.
gineering Building was re-named Latrobe Hall and it was designated
that the Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Building in the future
be called Maryland Hall. These two new names are quite appropriate
inasmuch as funds for the erection of the buildings were donated to
Hopkins by the State Legislature. Charles Latrobe, although he was
not directly connected with the university, was one of the most outstanding engineers of Maryland and the re-naming of the Civil Engineering Building confers upon him an honor worthy of his talents.
The Physics Building was officially named Rowland Hall in
honor of Professor Rowland, but this title, as well, is not in usage on

Discussed By S. C.
Woolen Will Address
Engineers Thursday
"High Pressure Gas Distribution" Will
Be Subtest Of Illustrated Lecture

Charles E. Woolen will give an
illustrated lecture at a public meeting of Gas Engineers' Association,
to be held Thursday, March 12, in
Room 110 M. E. The talk is scheduled to start at 4.15 P. M. His
subject is to be "High Pressure
Gas Distribution."
This is an entirely new idea in
the utility industry, according to
members of the Association.
Mr. Woolen is assistant superintendent of distribution at the local
Consolidated Gas & Electric Co. It
is expected that there will be a
large attendance present. from both
Hopkins and the gas company.

Enforcement Of Attendance At Asembly By Frosh And Sophs
Brought Up

The Student Council at its meeting last Friday, discussed the adoption of a new system of introducing
incoming classes to the honor system, according to Frank Cone, secretary-treasurer of the organization. Signing of the honor pledge
when the new entrant registers, will
probably be the method used, although details were not disclosed,
as they are not all settled.
Enforcement of assembly attendance by freshmen and sophomores
was the topic under discussion yesterday. This question, too, was also
left unsettled. However, 'members
are certain that a new method will
be inaugurated to cut down on the
large number of absentees.

University History Professor
Talks At Banquet In
Atlanta
FORTY ATTEND BANQUET
•-1

Stresses Fact Hopkins Future
Is 'Not In Past'
Dr. Kent R. Greenfield, Professor of European History, addressed
the Atlanta, Georgia, alumni of the
Johns Hopkins University, at the
annual banquet, held recently at the
Georgian Terrace Hotel. The history professor represented the University at this event.
Alumni from all parts of the
State of Georgia attended the banquet, it was learned. Among the
40 who were present .were physicians and college and university
professors.
Greenfield Addresses Alumni

Dr. Greenfield stressed the fact,
in his address, that "the future of
the Johns Hopkins University is
not in the past, as so many believe."
In speaking of his visit to Atlanta, the Hopkins professor declared that he was greatly impressed
by Emory University, on whose
faculty are several Hopkins graduates.
No Intercollegiate Sports at Emory

It was said that the Hopkins
alumni who are inkructing at
Emory are at present working on
a reorganization of the undergraduate schools similar to that being
attempted here. At the Georgian
institution, said Dr. Greenfield, the
students are apparently uninterested
in intercollegiate sports. "And they
are thoroughly happy about it," he
remarked.

Class Distinctions
To Be Eliminated

9ffice Manager

Chicago, Ill.—An impending revolution in undergraduate life stirs
the campus of the University of
Chicago, according to an Associated
Press release. In the fraternity
houses and commons, in the editorial columns of the Daily Maroon,
wherever students and coeds gather
to chat, talk centers on the metamorphosis of the coming year that
will sweep freshman, sophomore,
junior and senior from the college
vocabulary.
The traditional class system of
the American college is to be submerged, fraternity life overshadowed as students and faculty merge
in a new communal life. The
change is an incident of the Midway Institution's departure—after
only forty years of existence—from
the beaten path of higher education
to experiment with a flexible curriculum that imposes no restriction
on the student's swift path to
learning.

EDITORIALS
TOO MUCH FREEDOM
regulations and as many systems of

types of freshman
MANY
enforcement have been discussed since regulations were abolished

at Hopkins two years agp. There seems to be a manifest need for
some kind of regulation, but the idea of complete freedom has so
permeated Hopkins that undue opposition is always brought to bear
against anyone who is so bold as to suggest that regulations be resumed.
Last year we suggested a plan for enforcing a certain minimum number of regulations of which we approved. The suggestions, however,
seemed to meet with little favor. Since that time several new aspects
to the question have arisen and are well worth bearing in mind.
The construction of some definite program of intramural athletics has been a problem of considerable note at Hopkins during the
past several months. Any program adopted would be aided by some
type of freshman regulation. Since the abolishment of these rules, no
sort of athletic competition between classes has been held. Formerly
football and lacrosse and a track meet were held between the freshman and sophomore classes. Men who otherwise would participate
in no athletics whatsoever were given the opportunities which those
who strongly favor intramural athletics bemoan the lack of at present.
In spite of what may be said to the contrary, the average American
college student likes to feel that he is representing some organization
in any sort of athletic competition. Whether or not this body is a
college, class, or fraternity makes little difference. Freshman regulations are responsible for any organization in the present junior and
senior classes that exists at Hopkins. Few of the freshmen or sophomores know the majority of their classmates either by name or sight.
The requirement that freshmen and sophomores attend assemblies
has not been enforced until recently and hence, the attendance has been
very poor. The two lower classes have little respect for authority. Had
they been accustomed to regulations in their first year of residence, it
is doubtful whether the student could have been compelled to discipline
one-half of the members of the freshman and sophomore classes.
Freedom of action is a fine ideal, but some sort of regulation is certainly
necessary at times.
G. D.

New York.—After a search of
several years for the "ideal college
curriculum," to be used at St.
Stephen's College, the country undergraduate College of Arts and
Letters in Columbia University, located at Annandale-on-Hudson, the
faculty there declared in a New
York Tines article that there is no
such thing and never can be. This
statement was coupled with the announcement that hereafter the college would make an individual curriculum for and with each student.

gineering Building was re-named Latrobe Hall and it was designated
